Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Eocene Orbital-scale Oceanographic Variability in the North Atlantic: Inferences from Expedition 342 Cores
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks to develop a high-resolution, astronomically-tuned time series for the Eocene based on the isotopic compositions of foraminfera obtained from cores drilled during IODP exp. 342 (Newfoundland Drifts). This series will fill a gap (Eocene Gap) in the cyclostratigraphic record and enable the development of a complete orbitally-resolved Cenozoic record. This is one of the primary objectives of exp. 342. This work will also enable the examination of orbital-scale response and sensitivity of the carbon cycle during the Eocene and by comparison with data obtained in the Pacific Ocean, determine whether or not events such as the deepening of the CCD were global in extent. The Eocene is a particularly critical time for climate studies as it spans the time between the early Cenozoic greenhouse and the later Cenozoic icehouse. POR.DRECONTENT:
Constraining the rate of change of Earth system processes such as climate is key to reconciling the mechanisms (or effects) driving these changes.  With sedimentary archives, we have been successful in identifying patterns of climatic and other environmental changes that are influenced by periodic variations in earth’s orbit, the frequencies of which are well known. This project was aimed at providing the high-fidelity records required to link chemical and physical changes in deep-sea sediment cores to these astronomical cycles during warm period in Earth’s past –the Eocene (34-55 million years ago).  The goal was to better understand how earth’s oceans and climate behave in response to orbital forcing when global temperatures and atmospheric CO2 levels are higher than the recent past. Our research used a marine sediment record from the North Atlantic which was unusual for containing well-preserved fossils (important for the chemical analyses) and high sedimentation rates (important for working out the timing and sequence of events). We worked with teams of students to extract and analyze microfossils from several hundred meters of sediment core.  In general, the chemical composition of those fossils yielded a detailed record of climatic and environmental change in the warm middle Eocene, the first astronomically calibrated time-scale for that period, and thus a better understanding of the mechanisms driving variation in the earth’s climate and oceans in the past.  We also identified the presence of transient climate extremes, the exact origin of which remains unknown.  We will eventully use these observations to test the skill of climate models to simulate climate under greenhouse gas levels different than present.
